an6.56:4.1: Now at that time Venerable Phagguṇa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
an6.56:4.2: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an6.56:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an6.56:4.6: Sir, please go to Venerable Phagguna out of compassion.”
an6.56:4.8: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to Venerable Phagguṇa.
an6.56:4.9: Venerable Phagguṇa saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
an6.56:4.10: and tried to rise on his cot.
an6.56:4.11: Then the Buddha said to him:
an6.56:4.12: “It’s all right, Phagguṇa, don’t get up.
an6.56:4.13: There are some seats indicated by others, I will sit there.”
an6.56:4.14: He sat on the indicated seat,
an6.56:5.1: “Phagguṇa, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright.
an6.56:5.2: And I hope the pain is fading, not growing,
an6.56:5.3: that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
an6.56:5.4: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright.
an6.56:5.5: The pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
an6.56:5.6: its growing, not fading, is apparent.
an6.56:6.1: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.
an6.56:7.1: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
an6.56:8.1: The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like an expert butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
an6.56:9.1: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
an6.56:9.3: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright.
an6.56:9.4: The pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
an6.56:9.5: its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
an6.56:9.6: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Venerable Phagguṇa with a Dharma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
an6.56:10.1: Not long after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguṇa passed away.
an6.56:10.2: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.
an6.56:10.3: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an6.56:10.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
an6.56:10.6: “Sir, soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguṇa died.
an6.56:10.7: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.”
an6.56:11.1: “And why shouldn’t his faculties be bright and clear?
an6.56:11.2: The mendicant Phagguṇa’s mind was not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:11.3: But when he heard that teaching his mind was freed from them.
an6.56:12.1: Ānanda, there are these six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.
an6.56:12.3: Firstly, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:12.4: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.
an6.56:12.5: The Realized One teaches them Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an6.56:12.6: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:12.7: This is the first benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:13.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:13.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:13.3: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dharma …
an6.56:13.4: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:13.5: This is the second benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:14.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:14.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:14.3: But they think about and consider the Dharma in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
an6.56:14.4: As they do so their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:14.5: This is the third benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:15.1: Next, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:15.2: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.
an6.56:15.3: The Realized One teaches them Dharma …
an6.56:15.5: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:15.6: This is the fourth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:16.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:16.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:16.3: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dharma …
an6.56:16.5: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:16.6: This is the fifth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:17.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:17.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:17.3: But they think about and consider the Dharma in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
an6.56:17.4: As they do so their mind is freed with the supreme end of attachments.
an6.56:17.5: This is the sixth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:18.1: These are the six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.”
